Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Discovery and Dissemination of Neuromechanical Principles of Swimming, Walking and Running in Granular Media
Award.AbstractNarration: In this project the PI will develop a neuromechanics of locomotion on dry and wet granular substrates. This will be used to address how effective movement results from the interaction of body morphology and posture, muscles, Central Pattern Generators (CPG), and sensory systems with the physical features of complex environments like solidification and fluidization. The PI will study three organisms -- sandfish lizards, zebratailed lizards, and salamanders -- that respectively swim, walk and run effectively within and on granular substrates. These organisms will be chosen as representatives of effective locomotion in a given substrate: the sandfish swimming in sand, the zebra-tailed lizard sprinting over a diversity of granular terrain, the salamander walking in mud. The salamander also embodies features thought to be representative of early tetrapods. The project will use high speed imaging (both visible light and x-ray), granular force platforms, and electromyography (EMG) to record kinematics, dynamics, and muscle activity. The PI will develop controlled granular substrates using fluidized beds which will allow both creation of repeatable initial conditions and rapid perturbations to generate neuromechanical control hypotheses. Robotic models of organisms to test hypotheses will be built as well. The models will have relevance to organisms in the present and will be a step toward development of quantitative hypotheses of the evolution of movement on land. Understanding of the physics of soft materials like mud and wet sand will be enhanced. The work also has clear implications for robotics; in the modern world, in which disasters are common and affect many lives, there is a pressing need for devices that can explore complex shifting terrain. The PI will use the robots from the locomotion research to create hands-on robot modules to teach science by: 1) Developing and teaching a course in hands-on experimental science for undergraduates emphasizing principles of mechanics, electronics and biology. 2) Bringing K-12 teachers to Georgia Tech in the summer to learn to use hands-on locomoting robot kits. 3) Developing "Robotics Inspired Science Education" (RISE) nights to utilize robots to generate interest and teach principles of science to the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The terrestrial locomotion of running cheetahs, sidewinding snakes, and galloping ghost crabs inspires both public fascination and scientific interest. Most studies of terrestrial locomotion have focused on interaction with rigid, flat laboratory trackways. However, organism movement often occurs on or within complex terrain like sand, loose dirt and wet soils like mud. In addition, organisms likely evolved terrestrial locomotion strategies (in the “conquest of land”) as they moved from oceans and lakes onto flowing materials like mud and sand. Discovery of principles of biological locomotion has proved useful to create robots with capabilities approaching those of organisms in some environments. The robots also serve as physical models of the organisms, allowing tests of function and suggesting hypotheses of mechanical and nervous system control. To students and the public, robots represent exciting new technology-- interest in these devices is at a similar high level to that in personal computers 30 years ago. 

During the funding period of this CAREER grant my group (consisting of  ~20 postdocs, graduate students, undergraduates and high school students) has studied a diversity of animals and robots on and within dry granular media  seeking to discover common principles of movement and neuromechanical control. Broadly we have shown the importance of proper creation and manipulation of fluid and solid-like aspects of the substrate during movement. We have developed techniques to control and create uniform repeatable states of granular media (e.g. fluidized beds), in lab and field studies. We have pioneered use of high speed x-ray imaging to monitor and track movement of snakes and lizards within the substrates (the first such observations). And we have developed numerical and  theoretical tools (more below) to analyze the motion. We work comparatively, using animals that effectively locomote on or within dry granular media; these have included sand-swimming lizards and snakes, sidewinder rattlesnakes, hatchling sea turtles, and mudskipper fish.

Following pioneering efforts of biologists and engineers, we have studied robots as physical models of the organisms; such systems allow parameter variation that is inconvenient or impossible in the living systems or in mathematical models. However, when I first began the grant, robot experiments were still challenging -- I had to rely on using robots that my robotics colleagues created.  However, I soon realized that physicists too could build simple robots, and when integrated into our animal and soft matter studies (see below) make real contributions to engineering (like Best Paper awards at robotics meetings) and biology. In the last ~5 years, this has accelerated: largely due to 3D printing and powerful servo-motors and controllers, we can now rapidly design and construct our own robots and subject them to systematic tests over a large parameter space (aided by automated data collection systems we have developed). We are calling this type of study “robophysics” and have written a review article and hosted two Focus Sessions at the APS March Meetings (2016/2017) with plans for a third Focus Session in 2018 along with a tutorial at the meeting.  One example of the fruitfulness of the robophysics approach has been our interactions with evolutionary biologists to use animal and robophysical models to shed light on early vertebrate terrestrial locomotion; a paper on this work was published in the journal Science in 2016, and the lead author was an undergraduate physics major.

I believe that educating students about the process of scientific  research can play an important role in the development of critical thinking and reasoning skills. To integrate research into my classroom teaching, I developed two hybrid lecture/“hands-on” courses at Georgia Tech: One of these is a Nonlinear Dynamics/Complex Systems course (http://nldlab.gatech.edu/) in which in addition to lectures, students worked in my lab on week-long “micro-experiments” that they designed and built. At the end of the semester, students gave research presentations and wrote a journal-style paper: the students became scientists for half a semester. Inspired by the success of this class, to facilitate interaction among physics/engineering and life science students, I created a Physics of Living Systems Survey Class  (hoppols.gatech.edu and Figure 4) built around modules on topics from protein folding to cell motility to neuromechanics to dynamical systems in ecology and evolution. Students received lectures and built instrumentation with low cost parts and their smartphones that enabled them to explore aspects of a module. For example, they made a ~100x microscope/40 kHz oscilloscope using their smartphones and used this “phonescope” to image cell phagocytosis, yeast evolution, and nematode worm locomotion. At the end of the class, the students created their own system (e.g. a servo-driven, Arduino controlled PCR machine) with a final reports and presentations discussing integration of experiment, simulation and theory.
